Entry.1: New Year's Day. A large mail is a good beginning to the year. Rest during day. Night duty of 13 hours as usual. "The Talisman" - Stormy Weather.
Entry.2:
Bad weather continues.
- Bernefay Wood. Its present aspect. I again meet Toby Barton.
- News from Australia. Social & Politicalunrest. Artillery bombardment N.W. of Albert - more wounded.
Entry.3:
"Skulthorpe". Continued storms. Capt Brown - popularity of the "Bully" . Still at BernefayWood.
"Daily Mail year book" - Artillery active.
Entry.4:
The death of Lt Col Lean - a great loss. Col Lean only 24 - Wife in France-A fine record 5 Brothers (3 Colonels & 2 Majors).
Neglect of wounds before arriving at our D.S. A great night for aircraft. Our own planes very busy.
Entry.5:
"Oh! that armoured train" - Fritzy comes very close with his shells. A rough night. Dressing room duties continue - trench feet & wounded.

Saturday,
Entry.6: Our "Belgian Canteen" re-opened - Roy in charge - great business. News from Ypres & Armentiers . German attack repulsed. French feat & its effects.
Entry.7: Harry & I visit Eric Gordon. Serious cases. The 7th loses another of its members. Death of PteLovatt,A.T.S. A wild night. Engineers' sad fate.
Entry.8: News from Headquarters "re" Anzac Concert Party - Self accepted as an artist. Quiet night as regards work. Otherwise freezing. Good news about Austria - Many "ferfies" current.
Entry.9:
Rain & wind. Orderly room reply to A.C.P. . Painless extractions (?) in dressing room. Artillery active.

Wednesday,
Entry.10: Pte Airey & self lead 7th to join A.C.P. A miserable journey during which I meet Roy Mc. Sorry to leave my pals, more so on account of genuine farewell wishes. "My roughest ride". Arrive at destination 11 p.m. Worn out. Cold reception.Restless night.
Entry.11:
After visiting Theatre at Mericourt, & getting an idea of things, my pal & I are beginning to think it would be better back with Unit. Theatre 5 kilos from billet. Show at night (medium)
- not yet in programme
- assist the hypnotist
- fun indescribable.
"A night to remember". Oh! That mysterious Aubrey!
Entry.12:
Awaiting trial. Not very anxious to succeed. Sgt Simmons (General imposter & impossible artist). Once more assist in "Hypnotic Act".
- New acquaintances:- Harry Ross, Hughie Gannon, Ted England.

Saturday, 13 January
Still awaiting developments. I am told I shall make first appearance on Monday. Will it eventuate? 
My twentieth birthday. Longing to be back with 7th. A miserable existance. The appearane of Staff Sgt Carlisle makes the outlook brighter. Sgt Simmons (contemps).
Entry.14: My bad cold continues. A trial at last. Successful. My pal fails. On programme for ensuing week. Sgt Hems & Cpl Britt.attached to Anzac Troupe.
Entry.15: Anniversary of departure from Australia. I meet Major Donald. Theatre afternoon & night. Opening show of new programme - "Gunga-Din".
Entry.16:
Heavy fall of snow. Airey returned to Unit also four others. Continuation of "Mericourt show". Make up self with better results. "Cease Fire".

Wednesday,
Entry.17: Rise 10 a.m. Correspondence. Theatre 3 p.m. Rehearse Pieces. Performance at night. Improvement of show "Gippsland Girl" & H Paradise.
Entry.18: Rise 9.30 a.m. Theatre 4 p.m. Performance 6 to 9 p.m. Voice better. "The Green Eye of the Yellow God".
Entry.19: The humour of our friend Harry Ross. More try outs at Theatre. Performance as usual. "Green Eye" & They Didn't. A fire occurs &causes three of our artists c.i.
Entry.20: Last night of weekly program. Repetition of last nights work. Bonus for services - "The Sketch".
Entry.21: Bitterly cold. More snow. A quiet day. News from the 7th. Apparent bombardments up the Line.Major Donald.
Entry.22: First mail since leaving the Unit. Coincidence of "The Moods of Ginger Mick". Miserable weather. Preparation during this week for forming etc. of "Troupe".
Entry.23: A trip to Merricourt to hear this weeks program. Impressions of same. Sgt Davy joins troupe. Freezing weather. Our Tenor appearing at Corbie.
Entry.24: Quiet day. Preparation of New Work. A Bath that was not enjoyed. "Greece comes down". 36th C.C.S. . Recreation Hut.
Entry.25: "Somewhere the sun is shining" - (Probably in Australia). Letter from Home. "Cafe au Lait". Another visit to Merricourt Theatre. Gen. Birdwood, his staff & also many nurses present. "Aubrey" once again. Clarrie Hems in his "Drunk Act".
Entry.26: "Moods of Ginger Mick". "Anniversary Day". Nothing unusual occurred.
Entry.27: Headquarters move from Heilly to Henencourt. Good work by 29th Division. Final show at Merricourt.
Entry.28: Sabbath. Our party moves from Heilly to Merricourt. Preparations for departure to new Theatre.
Entry.29: A Day of Labour. Weather still very bitter (e.g.). We move to Albert & take over Cinema Hall. A good billet at last. Bombs once more.
Entry.30: Another snowfall. A visit to 7th Fld Amb., pleasant re-unions - happy hours spent with the boys.
Entry.31: We give entertainment at Sergeants Mess of the 5th Fld Amb. A good night with a stormy ending.
Entry.32: Concert at 7th F.A. . Another pleasant evening. Fine reception.
Entry.33: A trip to Henencourt. Preparation of Theatre proceeds. Mail. Severe weather. Bombs.
Entry.34: Entertainment at Church Army Hut (Albert). German aircraft activity.
Entry.35: Rehearsal at Hall. Albert heavily shelled.
Entry.36: Weather still bitterly cold. "First night" of new Programme - many turned away. "Misfortunes never come singly" .
Entry.37: Continuation of programme. A much better show. More bombs. "Our messroom Guest". Death of Pte Luke.
Entry.38: Another good night - "Gippsland Girl & 'Er Majesty". Major Churchill. Freezing weather as usual.
Entry.39: Change of Program - same artists. "Lasca" & encore no.
Entry.40: Repetition of previous day. Critical situation in U.S.A. Souvenirs from Albert.
Entry.41: Last night of programme - "Fuzzy Huzzy" & "Muggins". Parcels from Home etc. Successful British raids.
Entry.42: A visit to the Ambulance - news of Harry. A quiet day - still bitterly cold.
Entry.43: New programme chiefly pictures. A weeks spell. Mail from Australia. Bert Miller's successful turn (Arch).
Entry.44: Special Programme (Troupe) given to 9th Batt. A.I.F. - a much appreciated show. Deput in Parrot Costume.
Entry.45: Rehearsal for next week occupies all the morning. (A much enjoyed meal from an old pal). Weather getting warmer. A thaw sets in.
Entry.46: Programme comprised entirely of Pictures.( "The Heart of a Painted Woman"). Very good. Accommodation insufficient - many turned away.
Entry.47: Rehearsal (9-12). Letter writing. Monologues - weather again good. Cpl Shaw joins our party (Courtney & Shaw).
Entry.48: Last night of weeks programme. Packed houses still. Very little news from the Fronts.
Entry.49: A visit to my friends at the Ambulance. Letters to Australia. Weather warmer.
Entry.50: New Programme proves a "winner". Pleasing criticisms from Officers & men. "Green Eye of the Yellow God".
Entry.51: A good night - success of all items. Continued success of Bert Millar's Turn (not forgetting Arch).
Entry.52: Weather getting cold again - prevalence of fogs. Where is our Mail? Continuation of Programme.
Entry.53: Letter writing & preparation for next weeks programme. 7th F. Amb. Mr Clements. Weather very cold.
Entry.54: Startling War News! Evacuation by Germans of strong positions. Its effects (?) We are indeed puzzled by new move.
Entry.55: Last night's show of a successful week. A surprise meeting of Sid Alder & myself. Robert Service.
Entry.56: A trip to Amiens which did not eventuate. Sickness in our "Home". Ambulance moves off from Albert.
Entry.57:
Change of Program.
- Packed Houses.
- Good results once more.
Entry.58: Rehearsal & Show. More interesting news re "Evacuation". Weather good.
Entry.60: Our usual two shows. After second show our Troupe proceeds to Becourt where an entertainment is given to 45th Batt. The officers mess - Whisky & its result on the Boys. A wild night.
Entry.61: News re Eddie Cornish. Sequel to last night's trouble. Rehearsal. Visit Ambulance. The "Two Wags".
Entry.62: Rehearsal & shows. The latter in which we do not participate. Day spent in writing & reading. British capture many.
Entry.63: Rehearsal. Visit Ambulance. Large mail received from Home. Still in Albert. Visit to 5th Division Concert Party.
Entry.64: No rehearsal. Day occupied in writing. Some of our members visit Amiens. A heavy fall of snow.
Entry.65: Change of Programme. Crowded houses. Success of New Bill. A very busy night - "Spotty".
Entry.66: Improvement of Programme. Oh! that sketch. Doing well with "Spotty". Neuralgia pays me a call! News of Harry.
Entry.67: Arrival of Properties from London. Mr Hyde - On the Road to Brighton. March winds.
Entry.68: Rehearsals. Snowfall. Request for "G. Din". Death of Count Zeppelin. "B Hollweg" dismissed. "Bob Roberts" joins "troupe"!
Entry.69: Rehearsal. An extra successful evening. "Spotty" still going strong. "Fred Reade" joins the Troupe. Busy days & nights.
Entry.70: Rehearsal. Last night of weeks programme. Usual shows.
Entry.71: Amiens trip cancelled. A heavy rehearsal. Correspondence.
Entry.72: Rehearsal. Two shows. Entertainment to 45th Officers (Anniversary).
Entry.73: Rehearsal. Two shows. Success with "Rosa". Correspondence.
Entry.74: Rehearsal. Two shows. Visit to Ambulance. Mail from Australia.
Entry.75: Good war news. "I lose a good pal!". Harold's departure for Unit. Usual rehearsal & shows.
Entry.76: Splendid War news. The "Anzac Coves" go to Breil and entertain 45th Battalion etc. "Spotty, Rosa & 'Er Majesty".
Entry.77: Capture of Bapaume. Trip to Millencourt where "Troupe" gives a most popular show to 600 Hospital patients etc - Spotty & 'Er Majesty.
Entry.78: Capture of Perrone & many other villages. A visit to Amiens. Troupe gives entertainment at N.Z. Hospital. Night show to 13th Batt Officers at Ribemont.
Entry.79: Anniversary of Landing in France. Celebrated by hard work. Debut with "Sentimental Bloke". Good reception of New Programme. Excellent war news.
Entry.92: Sabbath. Albert Hospital. Letters to Home. Interesting development in U.S.A.
Entry.93: Rehearsal & shows. New Programme, "Last Toast", "Cafe Burlesque".
Entry.94: Rehearsal & shows. Visit from Roy B. Declaration of War on Germany by U.S.A.
Entry.95: Special Entertainment to H.R.H. Prince of Wales - General Birdwood & staff of A.I.F. etc. Congratulations from Prince.
Entry.97: Good Friday. Visit "per foot" to Becordel. Unit. Wind Bag shows.
Entry.100: New Programme. Success of "B. of S.S. " Heavy fall of snow.
Entry.101: Great British victory at Arras. Canadians good work. Usual Routine.
Entry.102: Anzac's success but heavy price. Fourth Division cut up. Wonderful escape of our two Heroes Capt. Murray & Lt Jacka.
Entry.103: Further British successes. V.C. Robinson missing. Heavy fall of snow.
Entry.105: Rehearsal. Show. U.S.A. Australian successes beyond Bapaume.
Entry.106: Our Boys still doing good work on the Line.
Entry.109: Another journey to Mametz. Brig. Gen. Capt. Murray.
Entry.111: Re-appearance of "Anzac Coves" - Record House (706). Great night.
Entry.112: Roy Bice returns from Blighty & spends night at our billet. "Rosa".
Entry.114: Rehearsal & shows. Two nightly. Heavy fighting. Cambrai. St Quentin.
Entry.115: Rehearsal & shows. Australian Mail. More heavy fighting.
Entry.116: Anzac Day. Second Anniversary of "Gallipoli Landing". Celebrations in France.
Entry.118: Rehearsal & shows. Last night of programme.
Entry.119: Journey to Brayle where we entertain 12th Brigade Inf. Guests of 46th Batt.
Entry.120: Australian Mail. Heavy fighting by Australians.
Entry.121: Rehearsal & Nightly shows (2). New Programme. Mail. Activity of Air Craft. Rumoured offensives.
Entry.126: Illness of Hughie. Taken to Hospital. Bright hopes concerning Furlough to England.
Entry.127: Pozieres, Andy, Town Major's, Summer Weather. News of National Party success - very popular.
Entry.128: Pozieres. Duty H.R's. Movement Order from England. Leave.
Entry.129: Depart from Albert 2 p.m. Arrive Amiens per rail. Depart Amiens 6.30 p.m. Arrive Boulonge 11.30. Pass night in rest Billets.
Entry.130: Embark 10 a.m. at Boulonge for "Blighty". Cross channel under escort (1½ hrs). Arrive Folkestone. Disembark & Entrain for London. Impressions. Horseferry Rd. Queens Hotel. Coliseum.
Entry.131: Mirror Hall. Strand. Trafalgar Sq. W. Abbey. H's of P. Bank N.S.W. Tube. Waterloo. H. Rd. St. Paul's. Southampton. Mr. & Mrs. Crocker. Impressions of town. Girls. The Common. Bargate Pier. No .
Entry.132: Southampton. Leave for London. London. "Dalys". Euston. Picadilly. Leave for Scotland. Night in train.
Entry.133: Leave Glasgow 10 a.m. - mountainous country old castles. Impressions of Glasgow. Manufacture etc. "Grosvenor Hotel". Depart 3 p.m. for Edinburgh. Arrive 5 p.m. "Old Waverley Hotel". Miss Hater. Princess St.
Entry.134: Edinburgh. Sight seeing. Edinburgh Castle. Holy Rood Palace. John Knox. "Church & House'. Princes Park. Motor trip to Forth Bridge. Linlithgow. Castle. River. Navy.Barnton. Lord Hopetoun. Porto Bello .
Entry.135: Interiors of Edinburgh Castle. Holyrood Palace. John Knox House. Cannongate. Mary Queen of Scotts. "10 to 1". Motor to Roslin. Castle & Chapel. Architecture etc. Edinburgh disgrace. Lord Nelson. Colinton. Empire Theatre.
Entry.136: Shopping. Art Gallery. "10 to 1". Splendid news from Front.
Entry.138: Edinburgh. May 25th. Walter Scotts Monument. The Hill. Nelsons Monument. Cinema. Depart for London 10 p.m. My heart in Edinburgh.
Entry.139: Arrive London 8.30 a.m. Queens Hotel. Bank N.S.W. Finchley Rd. Mr & Miss Fitzsimmons. Recollections. Trip to city (St James & Hyde Park). Apsley House. Marble Arch. Bond St. Wellington Monument. Selfridges. Reynolds. Langfiers. Lyric (Roads).
Entry.140: St. Pauls Interior. Service. West End. Alford. Bransby Williams. L. Benstead. Chu-Chin-Chow (Greatest production). Magnificent spectacles. Haymarket etc.
Entry.141: Depart London 8 a.m. Arrive Folkestone 10 a.m. Rest Billets. Impression Folkestone. Embark for Boulonge. Arrive 5 a.m. Blanket Hill. "Are we down-hearted? Yes. Pass night Boulonge .
Entry.142: Leave Boulogne in cattle trucks. Arrive Etaples midday. Rest camp. Keith Harris. Miserable day. No rations - poor accomodation. Certainly a contrast to Blighty.
Entry.143: Etaples still. Unbearable. No news of rejoining Unit.
Entry.144: Reveillie 5 a.m. Entrain 5.30 at Etaples. Depart 7.30 a.m. Arrive Albert 1 p.m. March to new Quarters at Bouzincourt. Mail makes us all much brighter.
Entry.145: Our new quarters - beautiful environments - splendid weather - some solid work.
Entry.146: Working on renovation of Hall. "Australians" now out of line first time for ten months - all of which (with exception of 6 weeks) was spent on Somme front.
Entry.147: Mail from Sydney & also Edinburgh. Our missing pianist. Signwriting & carpentry (?). Sgt Dobson - news of Harry & Roy.
Entry.148: "U" Boat menace growing much weaker. Italian successes. Weather still glorious. Study of Ruskin (Early selections).
Entry.150: Rehearsal & Shows. Pianist still missing. Mail & Photos. Ruskin
Entry.151: Life under canvas. Senator Pearce & Leave to Australia for Originals. Situation on Wst Front unchanged. Ruskin. Dickens Show- poor house.
Entry.152: Andy's return. Ireland. Rehearsal & shows. (Full Pierrot).
Entry.153: Scheme of Commonwealth Govt to recall "original Anzacs". Rehearsals & shows. Hot weather. "Village of Bouzincourt" (Tunnel to Albert).
Entry.154: A long walk with Bobby Roberts. Through many villages for first time including Martinsart, Hamel, Aveluy etc. Early distraction. Shows.
Entry.155: Sabbath. Quiet day. Renewal of enemy air-raids on Blighty. "U" Boats. Correspondence. Bert Millar awarded D.C.M.
Entry.156: Two shows at village of Senlis. The limit in Halls. Popularity of Anzac Coves. Some hard going. Return midnight to Bouzincourt.
Entry.157: Warloy. Two shows to 2nd Div. Troops. Our Hall recalls memories of last year after Pozieres. Visit to my old Unit. Old friends.
Entry.158: Second night at Warloy. Two shows - great success. F.G.C.M. . Again meet Harry. Divisional sports.
Entry.159:
Heavy storm as result of oppressive weather. Command performance of Anzac Coves to Andy Fisher (H.C.) & Officers of H.Q's A.I.F. Entertainment at Officers Mess.



Friday, 8 June
Two shows to portion of 5th Bde at Contay. (Old memories: Contay marks spot of A.I.F. H.Q's at time of Pozieres - also site of 7th F. Ambs. clearing station - the creek). Entertainment great success. A. Cleland. A rough ride.
Entry.160: The morning after the night before (Riot). Two shows to remainder of 5th Bde at Rebompre . Y.M.C.A. Hut. A day of starvation & inconvenience. Arrive back at Bouzincourt 1 a.m. News from Blighty.
Entry.161: Special show at Henencourt. Entertainment at 6th Brigade Sports to 2,000 men. Entertainment after show by
Entry.163: Back to Bouzincourt. Show. Rehearsal & two shows. 22nd Battalion in village.
Entry.164: Offensive at Messines & Ypres. "4th & 3rd Division scrap" - H.J.W. NaPoo. Two shows
Entry.165: Morning exercise. A little time daily for study. Two shows.
Entry.167: 22nd Batt leaves Bouzincourt. No troops in village. Consequently the Anzac Coves rest.
Entry.168: After 18 months I again meet Bert F. in 53rd Batt. which has come to our village. Old memories. Show again opened.
Entry.170:
Bouzincourt - Rehearsal & shows. "Cafe Burlesque".
- Own part made longer.
- "Sphinx & Woman".
- Ruskin.
Entry.172:
Bouzincourt. Rehearsal & shows - Letters Home.
- Tragic death of 53rd Sgt.
- Night manoeuvres.
- "Sesame & Lilies"
- "Sixes & Sevens" (O. Henry)
Entry.173: Entertainment at Training school (Toutencourt). Fine Y.M.C.A. Hut. Very successful show. 100 officers 120 N.C.O's & 200 men. "Pelicans" & "Curios" - Memories of Toutencourt.
Entry.174: Anzac Coves travel to village of Senlis. Two shows to 8th Brigade A.I.F. Russian Duplicity - Ruskin's "Sesame & Lilies".
Entry.175: Back to Bouzincourt. Rehearsal & shows. "Cafe Burlesque". "Bacon's Essays". Mail to Blighty. Despatch of parcels to Home.
Entry.176: Washing day. Reading (Bacon & Ruskin). Writing. News from Bert Millar.
Entry.177: Rehearsal & shows at Bouzincourt - success of S.B. - Birthday (19) C.H.
Entry.178: Rehearsal & shows. The curse of Drink is illustrated by comrades. Receipt of large Australian Mail. Rough weather.
Entry.179:
Bouzincourt - Morning & Evening Evening Exercise.
- Midnight carousals.
- Death of Bert Homer - Bert Ferguson - Ernie Murray
- "Ruskin & Bacon"
Entry.180:
Anzac Coves travel to Corp School at Aveluy.
- Entertaimet to 1,000 troops.
- Wonderful sucess - fine hall - Sgt Maclean. O.C. Lt Col Ross.
Hot shower (?)
Entry.181: Trip to Ouvillers - Scene of opening of offensive. Scenes of great destruction. A lecture on Stokes Mortars & the firing of same. Entertainment even a greater success than last night. Nurses from 9th C.C.S.
Entry.182: Entertainment to 8th Inf Brigade at Senlis. Failure of 5th Div. Concert Party. Tragedy of "picture-taking" expeditions.
Entry.183: Mail from Scotland. Correspondence. Cinema. Rough weather. British Successes. Anniversary of Offensive. Review by W. Holman & Gen. Birdwood.
Entry.184: Journey to Officers Hospital at Warloy. Entertainment in evening. Popularity of S.B. despite English Audience.
Entry.185:
Rehearsal. Leave for 7th F. Amb in afternoon. Old faces & old pals. Excellent treatment. "Coves" realise fine qualities of my Old Unit.
- "14th of 1st" - (Bellvue Farm).
​- Many dear friends missing.
- Successful Entertainment to the Boys. Very hard to leave.
Entry.186: Special Entertainment given to 2nd Division Artillery at Bouzincourt. Crowded House. "The Intro". Russian success.
Entry.187: Lecture in Hall by Gen Birdwood etc to 53rd Batt. Fine Oration on Morality & Venereal Disease by Archdeacon Ward of Victoria. Brilliant Speaking. Second show to Artillery. Record House for Bouzincourt. Loss of Mongolia. Nurses from Doullens.
Entry.188: Afternoon Entertainment to Staff & Patients of 9th C.C.S. (Aveluy). "Blood Orange". "My first swim for twenty months. A most enjoyable bath. Huge lake made in 1916 by French flooding the German Lines - Diving board etc. Movement Orders.
Entry.189: A day of rest after having Rehearsal. Russian's continued success. Reading & Correspondence.
Entry.190: British & Russian Successes. Henencourt Wood. Entertainment by 7th Batt. A.I.F. Preparations for departure.
Entry.191: Striking of Tents. Loading of properties & stores. Departure from Bouzincourt at mid-day for H.Q's. Ghost walks. "Mary Magdalene". Again meet Con Clarke.
Entry.192: Leave H.Q's in Lorries for Hazebrouck Familiar country. Pass through Doullens, St. Pol, Lillers etc. Glorious country. Old memories awakened in "Morbecque". Arrive Hazebrouck 3.30 p.m. Unloading duties.
Entry.193: Billeted in French Farmyard. More Labour. "Bean coup" bombs from German Aeroplanes dropped on town. Survey of Hazebrouck. Rubaiyat of O. Khayyam.
Entry.194: Morning Walk. "Tale of Two Cities". Air raids on London. Unloading of Lorries.
Entry.195: Second Anniversary of Enlistment. Our first show 'north' given at N.Z. General Hospital. "Tale of Two Cities".
Entry.196: Effective air raids by enemy on Bailleul, Dunkirk, Calais & Hazebrouck. Who said Ice Cream! W.a.d. French national day celebrations. Spectacular display in Town Square. We witness for first time another Pierrot Troupe (N.Z.'s), Tres bon.
Entry.198: Anzac Coves show for first time (North) at N.Z. Hall - Hazebrouck - a good & popular beginning. Busy day of preparation. Do well with the "Intro".
Entry.199: Rehearsal & show.Good houses. Another visit by Enemy Aircraft. Damage in Vicinity of Billets. "Tale of Two Cities".
Entry.200: Rehearsal& shows. Heavy bombardments. Activity of aircraft. Ambulance still at Becordel. Resignation of "B. Hollweg (German Chancellor). Rumored abdication of Kaiser.
Entry.201: Rehearsal & show. Change of Programme. Record Houses for N.Z'drs. News of Harold Williams ("Romeo & Juliet"). French children (?) (Egypt).
Entry.202:
Rehearsal & show. Rebellion in Russian Army - Good work undone - Poor Ration Supply - Dr Michaelis succeeds to Hollweg.
-War time profits.
Entry.203:
Rehearsal & show.
-Enemy aircraft.
- More Australian Mail Lost.

Sunday, 22 July
Entertainment given to Officers etc of 2nd Army Corps School at Morbecque - impolite & unwarranted treatment.
- Rivalry of
Entry.204: Div. Party. Aerial activity at night.
Entry.205:
Rehearsal & show. Change of Programme. Large parcel received from Home. "King of Golden River" (Ruskin).
- I do "Blood Orange" in character.
Entry.206: Fatique duty of loading H.Q. Lorries. Rehearsal. Show. Outdoor treatment nightly.
Entry.207: Rehearsal. Show. Air raid at night.
Entry.208:
Rehearsal & show. Fatigues. Change of Programme.
- "Spotty" (my own number).
Debut in East - Lynme Burlesque. "Con Clarke" & "Stan Bown"
Entry.209: The A.C.P. change their quarters. Under canvas again. Very pleased to again meet Harold Williams. Rehearsal & show.
Entry.210:
Rehearsal & show. Oppressive weather. Mail sent to London & Edinburgh (No. 16). A marvellous "flying" display by one of our airmen -"Olgy Cooper".
- East Lynne.
Entry.211: A Days leave to Calais. Leave Hazebrouck 9 a.m. train. Pass through St. Omer etc. Fine country en route. Arrive Calais midday - report R.T.O. - Visit Museum: Theatre: L'Eglise: The Beach & Promenade. Casino (now a Hospital) - Calais P.C. - Calais Castle (scene of successful English invasion in Middle Ages - Leave for Hazebrouck 5.30 p.m.
Entry.212: Rehearsal. Show. Change of Programme. "Rosa" goes better than expected. Nasty weather.
Entry.213: Bad weather continues & drives pal & self indoors to sleep. Return of Fred Reade after 4 mths absence. Mess Meeting - self appointed Secretary. Germans shell our town (Hazebrouck) first time for 2 years - Civilians terrorised. Our Show closed down in middle of programme. Populace flee. First show.
Entry.214: Town very unsettled after last nights bombardment. A visit from Will Dyson - who sketches stage etc. Big Offensive Expected. £.S.D.
Entry.215:
119
Air Raids on Town. Nasty weather interferes with Military operations. Change of Programme "Green Eye".
Entry.216: Rehearsal - Shows. Russian Duplicity. Presence of Americans. Continuation of nasty weather - News from Scotland.
Entry.217: Third Anniversary of War - "The Last Lap!" - Celebrations. Na--Poo! Rehearsal. Shows.
Entry.218:
Mrs P. Gallagher, B.A. - (Intelligence Dept).
- Will Dyson speaks "re" Ginger Mick.
- Air raids on Morbecque & Bailleul.
Entry.219: Change of Programme, "Bill Adams". More Australian Mail Lost. Anniversary (2nd) of "Lone Pine".
Entry.220: Rehearsal & shows. Issue of Rifles & Gas-helmets. Australian Mail arrives & I am considerably brightened.
Entry.221: Rehearsal & shows. "The First Hundred Thousand" (Ian Hay). Letter writing. Bonus from A.C.F. is productive of trouble in the camp.
Entry.222: Rehearsal & show. Major Churchill speaks out - Andy & Clarrie return to Units. New Pianist (Frank Donovan) arrives.Town Heavily shelled & bombed. "The House, Madame, & the Dog".
Entry.223: Town again shelled heavily - Populace terror stricken - We experience narrow escapes. Town all but deserted - some thousands flee to safer towns. Considerable damage - Version of Enemy Gun. N.Z.G.H. & R.T.C evacuate.
Entry.224: H.Q's & Staff Evacuate - Dark future outlook for Hazebrouck. Bad news from Scotland. Gas drill & inspection. German Socialists meeting in Stockholm. Rehearsal & show.
Entry.225: News from Harry. Capt Blacklock returns to Australia. Pope's Intervention for Peace. Britain's refusal for Stockholm delegates.
Entry.226: Change of Programme. Success of "This is the Life" (Revue) - a never-to-be-forgotten "Chorus" - "Ginger Mick makes his debut with satisfaction.
Entry.227: More bad news from Edinburgh - Bombs dropped on outskirts of Hazebrouck. Completion of Ian Hay's "First Hundred Thousand" - "An Anniversary".
Entry.228: Rehearsal & Show. Excitement owing to fire taking place in our Hall (Cinema Box). Labour demands in G. Britain - Mr. A. Henderson M.P.
Entry.229: Hazebrouck persistently shelled by heavy German Guns. A few land very near our billet. Last of civilians leave the town. Considerable Damage. Anzac Coves carry on as usual - "Boss".
Entry.230: Air Raids on our Town. Regular departure of R.F.C. . Australian Mail. Rumanian Successes.
Entry.231: News re the "Boys" (Marl. Herb. Hammy & Fred). Rehearsal & show. "The Melodrama".
Entry.232: Russian Reverses. Taubes drop 20 bombs on Hazebrouck. 20 military losses.
Entry.233:
Successful Entertainment at Vieux Berquin.
- D.S.C. - Cycling Corps etc.
- Air raids a nightly occurrence.
Death of four nurses & a score of "Pommies" at St Omer.
Entry.234: Another night at Vieux-Berquin. En Route we pass through Borre & Strazeele (July-1916).
Entry.235: British successes at Ypres. French victory at Verdun. Advance by Italians. Entertainment at
Entry.236: Further Italian & French successes. Major Murray attached to "King's Staff". We give a popular entertainment (in the rain) to the 1st Battalion, "Sentimental Bloke".
Entry.237: Elsie's Birthday. My Off-Day. Ill with Gastritis. Plight of Zeppelins.
Entry.238: Failure of Air Raid on England. Enemy losses heavy. "Kipps" (H.G. Wells)
Entry.239: "Kipps" continued. Preparation for Tour. Great Italian success. Excavation of Interior of Tents & Huts to guard against new German Bombs.
Entry.240: The Coves leave Hazebrouck 1 p.m. for Arques. We pass through Ebblinghem etc. (July 1916). Arrive Arques. Very bad weather. Very popular entertainment to 600 Hospital patients (No 4 Stationary). Arques Chateau.
Entry.241: Leave Arques for Wisques - 3 hrs in St Omer. "A wealth of Literature". Arrive at 2nd Army CorpsSchool - Avant la Guerre - "un grand Monasterie". Billet in gymnasium - Capt Reid - A most successful show. Bairnsfathercharacters - MAPS - GUNS - PHOTOS etc.
Entry.242: "A Parade to be remembered". Return to Hazebrouck (passing through St Omer). Second reading of "Mary Magdalene". A night off.
Entry.243: We travel to, & show at "Vieux-Berquin". "Na-Poo" & how it appealed to one Anzac! More air raids on Hazebrouck.
Entry.244: Again at Vieux Berquin - "Ginger Mick" goes big. "The Taube in the Search Light". Germans busy on Calais, Boulogne, St. Omer& Paris. Italian sucesses - continue.
Entry.245: "Vieux Berquin". Second number of "Ginger Mick". A coincidence in connection with same. "A Pocketful of Sixpences".
Entry.246: Correspondence. Visit 1st Brigade at "Sec Bois" where we give open air entertainment. Among others present were Brig Gen Leslie, Maj Brennan,Cullen, Ward,Stan Tindall & two old pals (R. Morgan & Freddy Turner) - A wild return.
Entry.247: The Coves again in Hazebroucke - Meet MrHenley & Mr Woodburn of A.C.F. 66 Victoria St London. Moonlight nights favour air raids by both sides.
Entry.248: Introduce a Daily Newspaper (one page written in ink) entitled the "Lubricator" (from which you get the good oil). Show at Hazebroucke. "The Bloke" - Correspondence. Mr. Henley.
Entry.249: Second number of the Paper. News from Harry. New German bombs & protection against same. Very busy these days. Show at Vieux Berquin.
Entry.250: Popularity of "Lubricator". Entertainment at Vieux Berquin. On the same Bill as "Charlie Chaplin". More chapters of "Pocketful of Sixpences".
Entry.251:
The lorry that did not arrive - and the rest we obtained 
therefrom
. German's capture Riga. Russian Retreat.
Entry.252: Entertainment at "Vieux Berquin". "Rosa". The Army crucifixion (First Field punishment). Study of Latin & French phrases.
Entry.253: Sabbath. Correspondence. Approach of Winter very marked in nature.
Entry.254:
S.M. Carlisle leaves for England. Show at Hazebrouck. Great unrest in Russia. Second reading of "The Cricket on the Hearth" (Dickens).

Tuesday,
Entry.255: The position very grave in Russia. Italian successes continue. Cold weather. "The Ring & the Book" Mr Henley (Browning).
Entry.256: "The Ring & the Book". Aserious split in the Russian Army - Gen Korniloff & Gen Kerensky - former marching on Petrograd. W. Front unchanged.
Entry.257: Successful all air raids. Civil War in Russia. We are sorely disappointed with our Ally. U Boats worst week. "Ring & the Book".
Entry.258: Position in Russia remains unaltered. Kerensky - C.I.C. Rumours of moving away. Change of programme.
Entry.259: A compromise in Russia. Acquittal of Lt Malcolm. Last night in our Hazebrouck Hall. We are joined by new member Les Williams.
Entry.260: A day of preparation for departure. "The Ring & the Book". Letters Home. Russian position much brighter.
Entry.261:
We leave Hazebrouck in Lorries after a solid morning's 
walk
 work. Proceeding to Belgium. Arrival at Halifax Camp (near Ouderdom). A busy day of preparation.
Entry.262:
Our new Camp. Hall & Billet - "Visions of the Somme". A day of hard labour. A night of shells & bombs. Steel Helmets & Gas respirators are brought to light.

Wednesday, 19 September
Anzac's great feat on a "near front". 5th, 6th &
Entry.263: Brigades solid & successful work. Advance of well over a mile. Incomparable & death dealing artillery. An impromptu show.
Entry.264: Day occupied in fatigues & Rehearsals. "Shell box" expeditions. Chinese Labour Battalion. Cinema entertainment to Australian Heroes. Enemy bombing raids.
Entry.265: Rehearsal & First Show in New Hall - "Na Poo". Further Aust. successes. Aust. Mail brings good & cheerful news. A bomb that dropped uncomfortably close.
Entry.266: What an offensive means as regards traffic. Frank Crossley joins the "Coves". Correspondence. "Old Goriot" (Balzac)
Entry.267:
Sabbath - Pick & shovel work continues. Return of S.A.Carlisle from London with a host of new properties. Old Goriot(Balzac). Aerial Activity.

- 150.000 -
Entry.268: Change of programme. Great work by "our Boys" supported by wonderful British Artillery. I again meet Harold Love - A talk of "people & places" (520).
Entry.269: Rehearsal (560). Pick & shovel work - and usual Show. Frank Crossley, a "hard old pro". Light Australian Casualties - but splendid results.
Entry.270: Rehearsal (458). Fatigues". Show - (Hundreds now being turned away nightly). "The Intro". Heavy Artillery bombardments. German Aircraft activity at night.
Entry.271: Rehearsal & Show (485). More British successes on our Front. The "Gotha" Plane. "Midsummer's Night Dream".
Entry.272: Rehearsal & Show(520). Increased traffic of Guns, Lorries, Munitions etc. Douglas Haig's promising outlook. An afternoon with H.L.
Entry.273: Rehearsal(602)& Show(500). Also special afternoon entertainment to "24th Batt." about to go into the line. Approximately 200 bombs dropped by German Aircraft in our near vicinity.
Entry.274: Sabbath. "The Merchant of Venice". Harold again visits me. Letters Home.
Entry.275: Rehearsal. Change of Programme. Great success of New Sketch. "The Play" - "beaucoup soleil" - beaucoup bombardment.
Entry.276: Rehearsal & show. Our Fifth Division make an advance. The Scotties saved from ugly situation by our Boys. Mastery of the Air certainly does not belong to British at present.
Entry.277: Rehearsal & show. Good summer weather. Offensive continues with great success. A new acquaintance Mr J Kirby late of J Knight, Oscar Asche etc. Reminisences.
Entry.278:
Rehearsal & show. Reading of "Twelfth Night". Great Activity on our New Front. ("A Hill" that was named before capture).

Friday,
Entry.279: Rehearsal & show. An influx of parcels. A couple of our Divisions withdrawn for short period - "Scottish-Australian fraternity". A decided change for the worse, in the weather.
Entry.280: Rehearsal & show. I again meet Ron Sheles& Stan. 2nd Div. in the Line. Voluntary surrender of many Germans including eight staff officers - "Winter".
Entry.281: Letters to & from Home (Parcel). Reading of Henry Esmond (Thackeray). 2nd Division execute splendid work.
Entry.282: Winter with a Vengeance. Rehearsal & show. A wild night on which we harbour lost Anzacs. 7th Fld Amb tragedy - death of S.S.E. etc & wounding of Jack Dunn & others.
Entry.283: First Division relieved by Fifth - Brilliant work by "Our Boys" - Roy Bice presented with M.M. Show. Correspondence. Completion of Henry Esmond.
Entry.284: Rehearsal & show. What do we think of the Pommies? After 9 months I again meet Roy who patronises our show. Sphinx & Woman. I read the "Blue Bird".
Entry.285: Rehearsal & show. "Sweet Lavender" (Pinero) makes interesting reading. Death of an old pal Norman Anderson ("Requisscat in Pace") - Fourth Division moves up to take the Line.
Entry.286:
Rehearsal & show. 
Success with "Sari Bair"
. Fortune deals unkindly with 14th Fld Amb (78 cas) - Crowded Houses.

Saturday,
Entry.287: I read "Passing of the Third Floor Back"(J.K.J. ). Air raids in our vicinity. No material damage.
Entry.289: Rehearsal & New Programme. Success with "Sari Bair".
Entry.290: A falling "Gotha" which provided a grand spectacle. An "express" visit to the wreckage & Hun victims. Show & Rehearsal - "Pompeii".
Entry.291: A visit from Roy Bice. News of old friends. N.Z's hard luck. Correspondence. Reprisals by British Airman.
Entry.292: Another very welcome visitor - (Harry Alder). Show & Rehearsal. German Bombs drop uncomfortably close!
Entry.293:
"Last Days of Pompeii". "Roy Bice & Sid London" all at the show. Naval Battles at Riga between Russians & Germans. Petrograd still in peril.

Saturday, 20 October
Letter to Home & Blighty. A proposed Xmas Pantomine. 1st Division relieve 4th Div. on Ypres front.
Entry.295: A visit to 7th Fld Amb. The fate of 5 Zeppelins all are brought down in France after return from London. In the midst of old pals for an afternoon.
Entry.296: Rehearsal & show. Matinee to 45th Batt. Again meet Eddie Cornish M.C. - "Who'll 'ave a Blood Orange?" Stormy weather interferes with offensive.
Entry.297: A new & successful French move - Much ground gained & many prisoners taken. Rumor of Holland joining Germany.
Entry.298:
Completion of "Last Days of Pompeii". The storm grows in violence. "Tom Sawyer" by Mark Twain.

Thursday,
Entry.299: A long & interesting chat with Eddie Cornish. Fourth Division move to St Omer. Show as usual. The storm subsides, and Fritz decides, - To visit us!
Entry.300: Still showing to crowded houses. A large mail from Australia. Bitterly cold weather. Completion of "Tom Sawyer".
Entry.301: Rehearsal & show. "Woodbarrow Farm" (Jerome K. Jerome). German counter attacks fail against Canadians & Australian.
Entry.302:
A Day's Spell. Beaucoup correspondence to Australia. Great defeat inflicted on Italians (80,000 men - 600 guns). Air raid on London.

Monday,
Entry.303: Trip to Belgian Chateau to see "Kookaburras". Very fine show. Return to our own Hall & play to record house. A night of very little sleep owing to Bombs.
Entry.304: Preparations for Panto. Show as usual - In addition to "Solo" item & concerted numbers I make my debut in comedy-drama (?) playing the Burglar in the Burglar & the Girl.
Entry.305: 29*The day on which the best of Anzacs & the greatest of pals, departs from this Life to join his "God & Mother" (R.I.P.),Roy Bice M.M. pays the extreme sacrifice & dies smiling.
Entry.306:
"The Dream" of the (?) previous day& an incident in the show. British reprisals on German town in daylight. Another Chancellor in the Reichstag.

Friday,
Entry.307: Panto. Rehearsal. A visit from Frank Jones & Jack Reeves.
Entry.308: A new crisis in Russia. Kerensky forms new Party & raises Army in opposition to Leninites & ( Pacifists). Show whilst the bombs drop.
Entry.309: Correspondence. I have the pleasure of meeting Mrs Hewett of Hugh Buckler's Co. & friend of Mr Campbells.
Entry.310:
Second trip to Belgian Chateau - "Kookaburras" show a falling off. Debut with the "11.69". Rehearsal & Show.

Tuesday,
Entry.311: A day of Air Victories for the Sopwiths. Another spectacle of falling Gothas. Italians still being repulsed.
Entry.312: Rehearsal in morning and in the evening we entertain "General Birdwood" & many Anzacs. Congratulation from our "Chief.
Entry.313: Rehearse Panto. Bitter weather. Read "Bab Ballads" by W.S. Gilbert. Show at night.
Entry.314:
Rehearsal & show. Completion of "Bab Ballads". A night totally devoid of rest-giving qualities. In other words - "Bombs"!

Saturday,
Entry.315: Rehearsal & show. I read Julius Caesar & write some doggerel. Last night of season on "Ypres" front.
Entry.316: A day of manual labour dismantling Hall, & preparing in general for departure.
Entry.317: An early morning departure from Winnipeg Camp (our late Hall). Passing through Neuve Eglise etc we arrive at Steenwerck and are billeted at top of an Estaminet. "The Five Sevens" (a fine show).
Entry.318:
Duties of unloading etc. During the day the greater part of 3rd Div. pass through Steenwerck. "Anzacs & Pommies" have a difference "re" ownership of Hall - naturally our side wins.

Wednesday,
Entry.319:
A night spent at the Ambulance where I become the richer by 
much
many Australian letters. Recollections of Zietoun & Cairo in conversation with J.S. - Jack Rob, badly wounded.
Entry.320:
We are still awaiting the departure of the Present Occupants of the "Theatre"(?). I meet many "old pals" including "Archie Martin" from whom I receive news of Charlie Walsh's death.

Friday,16 November
Steenwerck - Expedition for Ratiions. Our cook ("Bill") is badly burned and evacuated to "C.C.S." . A trip to
Entry.321: F. Amb where I meet many Liverpool friends.
Entry.322: Manual labour, in repairing our Hall, comprises best part of a day's work. "Black Rock" (Ralph Connor).
Entry.324: Italians making a stand. Rumours "re" Australians going to Italy. Heavy bombardments on Ypres front.
Entry.325: The Ghost walks. Colin Marsh. Rehearsal for Pantomime.
Entry.326:
"Thoughts & Afterthoughts" by Sir H.B. Tree.

Thursday,2 November
"The Anzac Coves" open in Steenwerck to a crowded House, & meet with great reception. Entertainedat
Entry.328: Great British Advance on the Somme. 10,000 Prisoners & 100 large Guns. Anzac's splendid display in Palestine.
Entry.329: Rehearsal & Show (9). In the afternoon we are visited by Official Photographer - and at night by Capt. Bean. Crowded House.
Entry.330: Letters written to Home & Friends. "The Coves" journey to Pont D'Achelle, where we entertain the 9th F.Amb. Midnight marauders.
Entry.331: In answer to a request, I again play football with my late Unit. More good news from the Somme. Weather bitterly cold.
Entry.332: Wet & cold weather. Apart from the Evening show the day proves very dull & is totally devoid of interesting events.
Entry.333:
Aust. Mail brings "Good Cheer" (47). Enemy aircraft 
attack
 active - Italy makes new offensive. "Hamlet" read during day.
Entry.334: Completion of Hamlet. More Australian Mail. The progress of Jack Dunn. His Brother Reg. Bitter weather.
Entry.336:
Further Russian treachery - Peace overtures with Germany. Roys personal belongings prove 
both
 sadly interesting - "The photo & the address". Henry VIII.
Entry.337: Rehearse Panto - ordinary show at night. Lord Landsdowne on "Peace". Completion of "Thoughts & Afterthoughts". A Band from 36th Batt temporarily joins our Party. Gen. Monash patronises the "Anzac Coves
Entry.338: An early rise, after which I prepare breakfast for the Boys - Porridge, Fried Bread, Tomatoes, Cocoa. Morning occupied in writing letters,(10).
Entry.339:
Rehearsal & show. Change of programme. Bitter weather. Aircraft activity around & about our Town. "Maladie-du-pays".

Tuesday,
Entry.340: I meet an old school pal - Roy Cooney (3rd A.S.C. ). The study of "Greening's Elocution". Rehearse panto. Night show as usual.
Entry.341: Rehearsal & show. Study of "How to Speak & Read" (Alston). Resumption (after long period) of a little Vocal Exercise (which does not promise to continue).
Entry.342: Once again London is heavily bombed by hostile planes. Fritz also gives the British a reverse at Cambrai. Aust.Troops sent hurriedly to that front. Change of Programme.
Entry.343:
Ralph Sawyer joins our Party. A grant of 5,000 francs to each Aust. Division is a "part-result" of the work accomplished by Anzac Coves.

Saturday,
Entry.344: For first time for 2 yrs I meet Frank Brainwood,Jack Duff & Charlie Brigden. Many Americans in the audience. A "Village Concert" Episode which concerns a mistake made by myself. Correspondence.
Entry.345: Correspondence & Reading(11). At night we journey to 1st A.C.C.S. (beyond Bailleul) and after giving a much appreciated show we are entertained by their Sergeants.
Entry.346: Rehearsal & show. Gen. McNicholl (C.O. of 3rd Div) in the audience. I again meet Colin Marsh.Good but cold weather.
Entry.347:
Jerusalem captured by the British. Russia refuses German Peace Terms. Rehearsal & Show.

Wednesday,
Entry.348: Rehearsal & show. "Thoughts & Afterthoughts". Visit the Ambulance. Gen. Hobbs patronises the Coves. German pamphlets dropped from balloons.
Entry.349: Rehearsal & show. Pte Davies joins the Anzac Coves. German chivalry (?) displayed by "airman" inflicting casualties (68) on Anzac Footballers.
Entry.350:
For the first time our show is interrupted by engine totally breaking down. However the "Coves" prove themselves under adverse circs. Bad news "re" 4th Div. being cut up.

Saturday, 15 December
7th Fld. Amb. leave Steenwerck - and take over from 9th F.A. at Pont D'Achelle - Mr McDonald evacuated - Mess meeting - "Othello".
Entry.352: (12) The arrival of a "new cook" retrieves lost hopes. Correspondence. Winter comes with a rush.
Entry.353: Change of Programmes. Japanese troops in Manchuria - Harold Williams pays a visit. We are also patronised by Nurses.
Entry.354: First snowfall this Winter. Bitter weather. Germans said to be massing on the near front. Portugese proving unwowrthy are taken out of the line - Succeeded by Anzacs.
Entry.355:
Still playing to crowded houses despite bitter weather. "U" Boats still achieving victories. An unfortunate conclusion to a good act (Bottle O!). Issue of Pantomime Programmes.

Thursday,
Entry.356: A severe frost, whilst making us all uncomfortable is the means of providing a most beautiful spectacle. Purchases for Xmas Dinner. Afternoon spent in writing & learning extracts from Hamlet.
Entry.357: A morning walk. Rehearsal & show. The frost thaws. "Richard II". Ï again meet Stan Scahill. A.I.F. goods for Xmas.
Entry.358:
Final preparations for Panto- "Macbeth". Correspondence. Xmas purchases for Mess.

Sunday, 23 December
Dress Rehearsal(13). Correspondence. Reading. Anzac Coves journey to "Le Strade" where we entertain 9th F. Amb. The Ambulance billet is one in which the 7th were billeted 21 months ago.
Entry.360: Xmas Eve. The "Box On". Pantomime postponed at last minute owing to Engine troubles. Disappointed Anzacs.
Entry.361: "Xmas Day" - Everyone in excellent spirits. Y.M.C.A. In our own Mess Room we celebrate the "Festive Day" which proves the Happiest & most Humorous since leaving Australia. The "topsy-turvy items". The Pommies & Anzacs on & in the Cat. The evening spent with 1st D.S.C. The end of a perfect day.
Entry.362:
The snow 
is
 still falling. Some beautiful landscapes. Final preparations for Panto. "Dick Whittington & Cat" a Huge Success. I meet with an accident.
Entry.363:
The Panto improves. Not so the weather. Further Italian reverses. News of a 
near
move from Steenwerck in the near future. The riddle of the moment. Where is the Aust. Mail.

Friday,
Entry.364: Promising Peace Parleys. Bitter Blizzards. Successful Show. Missing Mail. Coughs & Colds.
Entry.365: Rehearsal & Panto. "Modern Utopia". "Xmas Parcels received from Aust. Comfts. Fund. Heavy bombardment on near front.
Entry.366: Still the snow falls. More Peace Talk. "A Modern Utopia" proves heavy reading. A new move by British in Jerusalem.
Entry.367:
"New Years Eve". Pantomime Patronised by American General & Staff. The Passing of the Old Year - Old Memories & New Resolutions.

Tuesday,
Entry.368:
1918
"New Year'sDay". Öur Hall graced by Gen. Sir W. Birdwood who shakes with one & all after the show & is mightily pleased with his Concert Party -General Conor.
Entry.369: Two Aust. letters & a strange coincidence concerning one. The Panto (to-night) terminates most disastrously - a fire in which two engineers are badly burnt.
Entry.370:
(14)
News of Herb,Marl., Hammy & Fred being in England. More Panto troubles. Engine fails again. "The missing pin".
Entry.372:
Last show in Steenwerck. Most successful night of Panto - English troops now in the town. Anzacs depart - Mr Hewitt.

The Guard - & the French Barrage.
Entry.373: Fatigue duties at theatre. Preparing for departure. Cyril & self have most enjoyable stroll to Bac St Maur& are entertained by friends made early in 1916.
Entry.374: Advance Party leaves for Bailleul with Panto props & scenery. German Peace conference unsuccessful owing tonon-appearance of Russian delegates.
